text:
SPEAKER: How do you and the
Group think about turbulence

and how to deal with it
and how to prepare for it?

PATRICK CHALHOUB: I mean, it's
a very interesting question.

And often, we tend
to forget that we

are in such a turbulent
area, where things happen.

We have seen it after with
the Iranian Revolution.

Iran was an important
market for us.

We have seen it with a
lot of different wars.

And for us, today,
the name of the game

is speed and agility in order to
be able to react to a changing
environment.

Trying to just leverage
certain areas of risk,

we have always to
expect the unexpected.

And the best way we have found
to be able to adjust ourselves

to the unexpected
is to make sure

that within the organization,
and within our group,

we were able to take,
at different levels,

quick decision with
a certain agility

in order to adjust to the
environment, rather than a very

centralized decision
like the early days
of the creation of our group.

So really, speed and agility,
and we are all the time

struggling against
ourselves to make sure

that we have this agility
to adapt to a changing
environment about it.

Accelerate if the wind
are in the right side.

Decelerate if we have
to hold ourselves,

and we have adverse
winds against ourselves.

SPEAKER: Because you are
spread over multiple countries,

do you feel you have
an understanding

of forthcoming political
risks, for example?

PATRICK CHALHOUB: I
mean, we definitely
have a point of view.

But we try to remain
totally neutral
to any possible outcome.

And as I said, expect
the unexpected.
